This is a superb film, a German-Italian production directed by Christian Duguay (2009), 299 minutes. Young Augustine is played by Italian actor, Alessandro Preziosi, while 70-year old Augustine is played by the great actor, Franco Nero. Surrounded by the Vandals, led by Genseric in 430 AD, old Augustine, bishop of Hippo Regius in Africa, tries to stop the invasion even while he attempts to convince the citizens of this Mediterranean city not to fight back. The film works through flashbacks, from the last days of Hippo, besieged by the Vandals, to the early life of Augustine in Tagaste and his later move to Carthage, to study Law under Macrobius. His years in Milan, as Imperial orator, and his succeeding conversion to Christianity are powerfully  depicted. Focusing on two distinct phases of Augustine's life --first, that of reason, intellectual and carnal pursuits; second, that of the spiritual quest--, the film provides an engrossing picture of Roman Africa, with relevant contents, engaging rhythms, and an excellent historical reconstruction. Augstine's mother, Monica, is splendidly portrayed by the Italian actress Monica Guerritore, who represents a firm, dignified woman of great inner resources. The images for the film were inspired by the profound study of the mosaics of the church at Ravenna by Director Duguay and costume designer Stefano de Nardis. An extraordinary film, which should be seen by all interested in the life Augustine himself and the last years of the Roman Empire. Lastly, could I recommend that Amazon make available a version of the film for American audiences (Region 1), not only in PAL (Region 2)?
